title: Room 103

q1.prompt: Given the evidence, is the death a:

q2.prompt: If you believe it’s a murder, who is the killer?

incorrect.generic: That reading misses key contradictions in the scene and statements. Re-evaluate access, motive, and the ingestion setup.

bySuspect.Unknown Male (Lobby Silhouette): The silhouette was never forensically tied to the room—no prints, no phone overlap, no verified contact. It’s a tempting red herring.
bySuspect.Hotel Staff: Shift logs and access records place staff on routine rounds; no staff biometrics or prints match the wine bottle or glassware.
bySuspect.Other: No evidence-supported suspect fits better than the partner. If you name one, anchor it to access and a plausible method.

fullSolutionText: You followed the strongest line: with means, motive, and opportunity converging, the partner is the most consistent culprit.

reveal.motive: Jealousy and perceived betrayal after escalating conflict; control dynamics visible in recent messages.
reveal.method: Poisoned drink staged as a voluntary ingestion. The setup mimics self-harm but fails on access and sequencing details.
evidence: Message history shows escalating arguments and possessive language from the partner.
Partner had unsupervised access to the victim’s belongings and room-adjacent window of time.
Glassware/serving order inconsistent with solitary late-night drinking pattern.
Phone silence and delayed responses from the partner during the critical window.
timeline: ≈ 01:40–01:55 A.M. — Contact window where access to room was most plausible.
≈ 02:14–03:05 — Multiple unanswered calls to the partner (phone on silent per his claim).
Discovery — Staged scene suggests voluntary ingestion, but sequencing contradicts a true solo act.
reveal.epilogue: Alternative leads (e.g., the lobby silhouette) remain uncorroborated. The partner’s proximity, motive, and the staging inconsistencies point most directly to him.

title: The Last Appointment
fullSolutionText: You traced the timing, inconsistencies, and pharmacology. Dr. Sienna Hale is the killer.

reveal.motive: Professional rivalry and risk management; the victim had warned that someone was in her files.
reveal.method: A lethal Triazolam dose potentiated by wine, staged as a locked-room self-harm.
evidence: CCTV shows Hale entering at 19:59 and no recorded exit before TOD.
Vial with no prints; unknown partial on the glass.
Door locked from inside; spare unlabeled key in the desk; phone missing.
reveal.epilogue: You didn’t just name the killer—you proved the motive and the method. Case closed.

title: Forty-Eight Hours: A Cyanide Mystery
fullSolutionText: You pieced together the forensics, receipts, and draft article. Daniel Harper is guilty.

reveal.motive: To prevent Ethan Cole from publishing an exposé that would destroy Harper & Cole Technologies and expose fraudulent supplement ties.
reveal.method: Harper tampered with a bottle of 'Vitamin Boost – Energy Formula,' disguising it with a counterfeit label and ensuring Ethan consumed it within 48 hours.
evidence: Draft article directly names Harper & Cole Technologies in the fraud.
Lot code K3T-482 from the foil fragment matches the counterfeit bottle.
Transaction log shows the package delivery under suspicious initials.
Harper’s message: 'Some doors can’t be closed once opened.'
timeline: Sept 19 – Heated argument with Ethan at the office.
Sept 20 13:20 – Package delivered (Harper orchestrated counterfeit supplement).
Sept 20 evening – Ethan consumed supplement believing it was legitimate.
Sept 21 morning – Ethan collapses, later reports his own murder.
reveal.epilogue: You didn’t just name the killer—you reconstructed the fraud, the package tampering, and Harper’s motive. Case closed.

incorrect.generic: Not quite. Recheck the online order (lot code K3T-482), Harper’s threats, and the draft article evidence.

bySuspect.marcus alvarez: Chemicals fit the profile, but his inventory was intact and alibi supported.
bySuspect.lena carter: She had motive from financial strain, but her alibi during the package delivery is solid.
